work.name: Samsung AI Centre (SAIC), Cambridge
work.summary: I was leading the research on reasoning and neurosymbolic learning within SAIC-Cambridge.
highlights: I developed provably correct techniques that scaled logical reasoning to billions of facts and led to deep models with substantially higher accuracy.
I was the first to prove that we can learn neural classifiers using logical theories as the source of supervision, characterizing also learning imbalances in neurosymbolic learning.
I developed CPU-based techniques capable of scaling rule mining to millions of facts, taking less than 1% of the run time needed by the state-of-the-art GPU-based approaches.
I was the first to show how to efficiently answer queries in second-order logical theories that include millions of facts, while preserving the correctness and completeness of the answers.

work.name: Turing Institute, UK
work.summary: In 2016, the Turing Institute awarded me an early career fellowship, selecting me among more than 300 applicants for my contributions in logic and databases. My research focused on accessing heterogeneous data under privacy restrictions and logical reasoning both from an applied and a theoretical perspective.
highlights: I was the principal investigator of a project on accessing distributed NHS data under formal privacy guarantees, receiving funding of Â£100K from the Turing and the FARR institutes.
I developed provably correct techniques for accessing remote data under formal privacy guarantees.
I developed the first technique for efficiently answering queries over Web-scale knowledge graphs under complex logical theories under guarantees on the correctness and completeness of the answers.

work.name: Department of Computer Science, University of Oxford, UK
highlights: I theoretically established whether and how to answer queries subject to access restrictions and data constraints under guarantees on the completeness of the answers.

I led a project on accessing data from the European Bioinformatics Institute (EBI), the National Centre for Biotechnology Information (NCBI), and the Kyoto Encyclopaedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG), being awarded an EPSRC IAA grant.

work.name: Department of Computer Science, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, GR
highlights: I led a nationally funded project on querying data sitting in Cloud infrastructure.

work.name: Information Technologies Institute, Centre of Research and Technology Hellas (CERTH), GR
highlights: I developed techniques for video understanding that were published in the IEEE International Conference on Image Processing.

work.name: Artificial Intelligence and Information Analysis Lab, Department of Computer Science, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, GR
highlights: I developed computer vision techniques that were published in the IEEE Transactions on Image Processing journal.

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
